abstract.p: The overall improvement in mortality following severe burns has dramatically increased in the last half century with enhanced methods of resuscitation, treatment of inhalation injury, control of infection, early wound excision and novel methods of skin resurfacing. Although burn care begins at the onset of injury, reconstruction and rehabilitation feature highly throughout the various stages of treatment. Ultimately, we will have achieved little if the patient cannot be integrated back into society. For descriptive purposes burn care has been considered chronologically under the following headings: (1) First Two Minutes (Prehospital Care/First Aid), (2) First Two Hours (Emergency Room care), (3) First two days (resuscitation), (4) First Two Weeks (surgical excision and grafting), (5) First Two Months (rehabilitation and psychology), (6) First Two Years (reconstruction).

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The care of the burned patient begins the minute the injury takes place and continues until the patient is finally rehabilitated into society. Over the course of treatment, there are a number of dramatic and pathophysiological changes, so that modification of treatment is essential as the process evolves. The burn injury, therefore, can be considered as a series of phases which will be discussed in separate sections.

sec.title: The first 2 minutes (prehospital care/first aid)
sec.p: The initial treatment of thermal injury begins at the scene and should halt the burning process. Patients must be rapidly removed from the source of injury. Flames are best extinguished by smothering the patient in a blanket or getting the patient to “Stop, Drop and Roll.” First responders should protect themselves from contact with chemicals. Dry agents should be brushed off and the skin irrigated with copious quantities of clean water for 20–30 minutes. Patients with electrical injuries are removed from contact with the electrical source. All burned clothing should be removed, unless firmly stuck.

In minor burns, cooling is beneficial if started within 3 hours of injury, significantly reducing pain. It has also been shown to reduce the depth of a burn by decreasing cell metabolism, increasing dermal perfusion and dampening the inflammatory response; the latter by reducing the release of histamine and lactate and by decreasing levels of thromboxane (Cuttle et al., 2009). Cooling, however, has been found to be more effective if the wound is flushed rather than immersed and is ineffective if delayed (Baldwin et al., 2012). First aid recommendations guard against the use of ice and prolonged cooling, which can cause hypothermia and/or frostbite (Demling et al., 1979).

Patency of the airway is vital. If the patient is unconscious or exhibiting signs of respiratory distress, such as hoarseness or stridor, endotracheal intubation should be performed. All victims of fires should receive 100% oxygen to reduce severity of carbon monoxide poisoning. Life-threatening injuries are appropriately managed, haemorrhage is controlled and fractures stabilized. The patient is kept warm and covered with a clean dry sheet for transport. The wound and blisters are left undisturbed. Ointments should not be applied since wound assessment, necessitates removal by the medical team, which is painful, delays treatment and can cause tissue damage.

sec.title: Airway management
sec.p: Intubation is only indicated when the airway is threatened, gas exchange or compliance mandate mechanical ventilatory support, or for airway protection when mental status is inadequate. Although there is no indication for prophylactic intubation for inhalation injury alone, the patient should be carefully monitored since airway edema can evolve during the resuscitation period.

sec.title: Fluid resuscitation
sec.p: Following a burn there is a massive release of chemical mediators, including histamine, complement, arachidonic acid, products of the coagulation cascade, cytokines and oxygen free radicals. The result is an increase in vascular permeability and microvascular hydrostatic pressure resulting in an imbalance of physical forces controlling fluid flux across the capillary as fluid passes from the vascular to the interstitial compartments. In burns greater than 25% total body surface area (TBSA) these changes are also seen in nonburned tissue. Failure to correct the fluid losses will result in decreased cardiac output, renal failure and cardiovascular collapse (Demling, 2005). Injury may also occur at the cellular level, and a progressively diminishing cell membrane potential and cellular shock may be the final common pathway to multiorgan failure and death. Resuscitation following thermal injury, however, is complicated because huge transvascular fluid shifts occur, and the resulting obligatory burn edema has attendant risks of increased vascular compromise, airway obstruction and conversion of a viable, deep second-degree burn to a nonviable, full-thickness injury, increasing morbidity and mortality. A new term “resuscitation morbidity” has been coined to include such sinister complications as abdominal compartment syndrome (Kirkpatrick et al., 2009). Thus, the basic principle of fluid resuscitation is to carefully titrate the fluids administered to provide the least amount necessary to maintain adequate organ perfusion. Intravenous fluid resuscitation is required for all patients with second- and third-degree burns greater than 10% TBSA in patients younger than 10 or older than 50 years of age and for those with greater than 20% TBSA in all other age groups. Venous access is best obtained by large-bore (16-gauge) catheters, preferably placed percutaneously through nonburned skin, although central access may be necessary. These patients also require a Foley catheter and a nasogastric tube.

sec.title: Burn size
sec.p:
Traditionally fluid requirements are calculated from mathematical formulae related to the weight of the patient and the size of the burn, the latter most simply estimated from the “rule of nines” (Knaysi et al., 1968) (Figure 1) (Allgöwer and Siegrist, 1975) or body surface area charts such as that described by Lund and Browder (1944). All current methods have the inherent problem of transferring a three-dimensional (3D) injury onto a 2D piece of paper for analysis and so have limited accuracy. The use of the patient’s hand to estimate irregular or scattered burned areas is described and approximates to just less than 1% TBSA. This has been estimated when considering the hand as a rectangle. Modern methods using electronic devices may reduce some of the guesswork; however the future requires 3D body measurement for greater accuracy (Miller et al., 2002). Figure 1.
The rule of nines.

sec.title: Formulae
sec.p: There are numerous formulae that can be used for successful fluid resuscitation, however, no prospective randomized studies have been undertaken to enable comparison, and all formulae are only a starting point. The volume administered should be continuously titrated to the urine output to avoid over-resuscitation or under-resuscitation. Increased fluid requirements are seen following inhalation injury, after high-voltage electrical injuries, and in children. The most popular fluid used for resuscitation in the United States is lactated Ringer’s solution, with a sodium concentration of 130 mEq/l. This solution is most commonly prescribed for adults, using the Parkland Formula and recommends 4 ml/kg/h with half the volume given in the first 8 h. This was calculated to produce a urine output of 0.5 to 1 ml/kg/h.

Pigmented urine resulting from the presence of hemochromogens is often associated with high-voltage electrical injuries (>1000 volts). To avoid injury to the renal tubules, the pigment should be cleared as quickly as possible. The rate of crystalloid infusion can be increased to produce a urine output of 2 ml/kg/h. Mannitol can be administered to facilitate the diureses, and sodium bicarbonate can be used to alkalinize the urine to decrease the precipitation of myoglobin in the renal tubules. Rhabdomyolysis may be complicated by hyperkalaemia, and serum potassium should be monitored frequently until the urine clears.

sec.title: Treatment of mass casualties
sec.p:
It may be somewhat impractical, however, to use formulae when large numbers of casualties are seen and several alternative regimens have been described. The ISR “Rule of Tens” (Chung et al., 2010) calculates for patients 40–80 kg the initial hourly rate of IV fluids by multiplying the % TBSA burn by 10. For patients over 80 kg, 100 cc is added for every additional 10 kg. During the First Gulf War, mathematical calculations were simplified by assuming the patients to be of standard weight (appropriate for a military setting) and displaying the information in simple tabular form (Milner et al., 1993). Later this concept was expanded for use in the civilian population and included children. Multiple tables were represented in disc form, which progressed to the “Burn Wheel” (Milner and Rylah, 1993). The process was subsequently automated by a computer program, which ran on a hand held device (Roth et al., 1997). More recently, we have produced a mobile application which provides an input component where the health care provider is able to manipulate a 3D model and an output component that provides a treatment plan, which includes a comprehensive tutorial on how to perform each step (Figure 2(a) and (b)). Figure 2(b) illustrates how sites inaccessible on the burn surface area chart can be mapped on the 3D model. Figure 2.
(a) Burn application. (b) Comparison three-dimensional (3D) model and standard burn chart.

sec.title: Children
sec.p:
Fluid resuscitation requirements differ in children. When venous access cannot be accomplished, fluid can be delivered by cannulation of the bone marrow. A 16-gauge spinal needle can be inserted directly into the tibial plateau, medial malleolus, anterior iliac crest or distal femur and used to deliver fluid rates of up to 100 ml/h. Because children have a disproportionately larger head, they are best resuscitated with formulae based on surface area rather than weight, such as the modified Carvajal formula used in Galveston, Texas (Table 1), and urine output should be titrated to 1 ml/kg/h. Body surface area can be obtained from a standard height-weight nomogram (Table 2) (Carvajal, 1977). Lactated Ringer's solution is prescribed for children older than 2 years; however, infants younger are prone to hypoglycemia because of small glycogen stores and therefore should receive a dextrose-containing electrolyte solution. sec.title: Colloid
sec.p: The oncotic pressure generated by plasma proteins serves to maintain the intravascular volume. Following all resuscitative regimens, severe hypoproteinemia is seen following major burns, and this in turn potentiates further edema. The administration of colloid is therefore logical but controversial, and much debate exists as to when capillary integrity is established and whether infused protein stays within the vascular compartment. Experimentally this has been shown to be at about 8 h after the burn injury (Demling, 1987). Therefore, colloids generally are prescribed in burns greater than 40% TBSA, after the first 8 h and in patients with oliguria who are not responding to crystalloid resuscitation. The choice of protein solution is either fresh frozen plasma (0.5–1 ml/kg/%burn) or albumin, which can be conveniently given by adding 50 g of albumin to each liter of crystalloid. Fresh frozen plasma has the theoretical advantage of replacing clotting factors and is the colloid of choice when the INR goes above 1.5. It also contains fibronectin, an adhesion molecule and key fibroblast-derived signal protein, which helps initiate healing of the burn wound.

sec.title: Burn depth
sec.p: Classification of the depth of burns has traditionally used the degree system. First degree involves the epidermis only; second degree (or partial thickness) burns extend into the dermis and third (or full thickness) burns destroy the entire skin. An additional fourth degree is sometimes used to describe injury to underlying muscle, tendon or bone. A more practical classification is to describe burns as either superficial or deep as this determines both treatment and prognosis. Superficial burns involve the papillary dermis, with its rich vascular plexus, and the epidermis which contain sufficient epithelial appendages to allow healing within 2 weeks with minimal scarring. They appear wet, pink, blistered, blanch with pressure and are painful. Deep burns, however, involve reticular dermis and subcutaneous fat, have insufficient epithelial appendages. If healing occurs, it will be slow with resultant unstable skin, hypertrophic scarring and contracture, best treated by excision and skin grafting. Their appearance ranges from cherry red, mottled, white and nonblanching to leathery, charred and brown.

While bedside evaluation of very superficial or deep wounds presents little diagnostic difficulty, clinical assessment of the “indeterminate” or mid-dermal burn is accurate in only about two thirds of cases (Heimbach et al., 1992). Thus, more sophisticated techniques have been developed to assist accurate diagnosis (Devgan et al., 2006). Ultrasonography, biopsy, various optical means such as orthogonal polarization spectral imaging, thermography and nuclear magnetic resonance imaging have been employed but have been found to be neither reliable nor practical. Newer developments focus on measurements of tissue perfusion. Laser Doppler imaging which scans a burned area and generates a colour-coded perfusion map corresponding to various burn depths is the latest and most accurate modality for diagnosing burn wound depth (Milner et al., 2005; Pape et al., 2001; Still et al., 2001).

sec.title: Wound care and escharotomy
sec.p: The burn wound is carefully inspected, loose skin debrided and the depth and size of the burn charted. The treatment of blisters is controversial. We favour removal since the contained metabolites of arachidonic acid and other inflammatory agents in blister fluid may be a factor in converting the wound to a deeper injury. Systemic antibiotics are rarely able to reach areas of avascular eschar and increase the risk of opportunistic infections. Silver sulfadiazine (a.k.a. Silvadene®, Thermazene®, Flamazine® and SSD®) is the most commonly used prophylactic topical antimicrobial in burn patients. It is used for deep or infected wounds. SSD is an insoluble, white cream, available in a 1% concentration and is applied twice daily. It has the advantages of being relatively painless to apply, and its activity against a wide variety of organisms, including S. aureus, E. coli, Klebsiella, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Proteus, the Enterobacteriaceae and Candida albicans.

Prospective studies have concluded that in superficial burns infection is uncommon, that there is no difference in overall wound healing rates between nonantibacterial and antibacterial impregnated dressings (Nance et al., 1972) and that infection rates are not influenced by the specific antibacterial agent (Heinrich et al., 1988). Nevertheless it is customary to protect the wound with nonadherent dressings such as vaseline gauze supplemented with topical antibacterial agent such as bacitracin, neomycin and polymyxin B.

Deep burns which are circumferential may act as a tourniquet around a limb as edema develops so that it is necessary to make relieving incisions through the eschar to prevent vascular impairment (Pruitt et al., 1968). The decision to operate is performed on suspicion and should be made early since once palpable pulses are absent muscle necrosis may have already occurred. Direct measurement of compartmental pressures may be helpful and a wick catheter technique has established the need for escharotomy at a threshold of 30 mm Hg (Saffle et al., 1980). Once escharotomies are performed, continued monitoring is necessary to identify recurrence of elevated pressures.

Incisions are made along the mid-lateral lines extending from the proximal to the distal extent of the burned area. They should not be carried across joints and should be deep enough into the superficial fascia to allow the wound edges to separate. Bleeding is controlled with electrocautery. In the upper extremity care is taken to avoid injury to the ulnar nerve, behind the medial epicondyle, and the superficial radial nerve over the dorsum of the wrist. The latter is easily injured if the hand is not kept palm upwards during the procedure. Similarly, deep burns around the trunk can impede the patient’s ability to breathe. sec.title: Inhalation injury
sec.p: Inhalation injury constitutes a major cause of mortality following thermal injury. It is defined as aspiration of superheated gases, steam, hot liquids or noxious products of incomplete combustion which cause a number of physiological abnormalities. Mucosal edema, bronchospasm, intrapulmonary shunting and ventilation/perfusion mismatch contribute to respiratory failure and this may be further complicated by secondary infection leading to tracheobronchitis and pneumonia (Mlcak et al., 2007). The diagnosis is made chiefly by history and physical examination and can be confirmed by bronchoscopy, which may reveal carbonaceous endobronchial debris and mucosal ulceration (Massanes et al., 1994). It should be particularly suspected in patients who have sustained burns in a closed space and have deep burns of the face. Early chest x-rays are routinely normal. The PaO2/FiO2 ratio of less than 300 indicates a degree of intrapulmonary shunting and serum carboxyhemoglobin percentage is also of value. Intubation is required for all patients with threatened airways and those who require mechanical ventilation.

At high concentrations, carbon monoxide binds avidly to haemoglobin and other iron-containing enzymes, including those in the mitochondria and can interfere with delivery and utilization of oxygen. In all, 100% oxygen should be administered for 6 to 12 h, which reduces the half life of COHgb from approximately 2.5 h to 40 min. Significant exposure may manifest as headache, irritability, personality changes, loss of memory and gross motor deficits, and patients are at risk of developing both acute and delayed neurologic sequelae. Children and pregnant women and their foetuses are said to be at particular risk. The data supporting the use of hyperbaric oxygen is not strong (Seger and Welch, 1994) but may be appropriate for those with documented or strongly suspected serious exposures (carboxyhemolobin levels >25%) with depressed mental status (Ireton-Jones et al., 1987).

sec.title: Fluid resuscitation in the second 24 h
sec.p: After 24 h, extravasation of fluid from the microcirculation is minimal, serum sodium levels are high and protein is low. However, maintenance requirements may be high because there is continued evaporative loss from the raw surface of the burn wound. Thus, urine output can be maintained by hypotonic solutions such as D5 1/2N Saline. The addition of dextrose is necessary because glucose stores are depleted by catecholamine release. Protein losses should be replaced to minimize further edema and restore blood volumes when albumin levels fall below 1.5 mg/l. The volumes of enteral nutrition, usually begun at approximately 6 h, are factored into any calculations.

sec.title: Paediatric resuscitation
sec.p: In the following 24 h, fluid requirements are 3750 ml/m2 TBSA (to replace losses caused by evaporation from the wound) plus 1500 ml/m2 TBSA (for maintenance).

sec.title: Burn nutrition
sec.p: Enteral feedings should commence within the first 24 to 48 h from the time of burn. It should be advanced to goal quickly to preserve gut mucosal integrity, prevent bacterial translocation, achieve nutritional goals in the hypermetabolic state and promote wound healing. With the sustained increase in energy consumption, there is a parallel increase in energy demand and a shift in substrate use from glucose to amino acids as the preferred source of fuel. The result is mobilization of amino acids and protein catabolism with loss of muscle and other proteins. The hypermetabolic response is perpetuated by fever, pain, burn eschar, multiple surgical procedures and recurrent infection and may last until wound closure is achieved.

Actual energy requirements are best determined by use of indirect calorimetry within the first 72 h after the burn injury and weekly thereafter. There are, however, several predictive equations that can be used to estimate total caloric requirements. We have found the use of the Ireton-Jones equation to be the most consistently applicable to our adult population in determining resting metabolic rate. The Curreri and Harris-Benedict equations have been found to overestimate and underestimate caloric requirements, respectively (Cureri et al., 1974, Harris and Benedict, 1919). In larger burns (>20% TBSA), protein should be provided as 20% to 25% of the total calories, or 1.5 to 2.5 g protein per kg of body weight.

Elevated C-reactive protein (CRP) levels are indicative of the stress response and should be monitored in conjunction with prealbumin and transferrin. Albumin does not reflect acute changes in nutritional status because of its sensitivity to fluid shifts, plasma leakage and a longer half-life and therefore should not be used as a nutritional marker. Glucose control (80–110 mg/dl) has been associated with improved clinical outcomes, and insulin, being an anabolic hormone, may assist in nitrogen utilization and retention.

sec.title: Surgical excision
sec.p: For deep partial thickness and full thickness burns, operative wound excision and skin grafting are paramount. Wound debridement removes necrotic tissue which acts as a nidus for proliferation of bacterial and invasive burn sepsis.

Since the report of Janzekovic (1979), it has been shown that early excision and wound closure decrease infection rate and shorten hospital stay (Burke et al., 1974). In addition, this technique has been shown to benefit indeterminate burns, decreasing the severity of hypertrophic scarring, joint contractures and speeding rehabilitation (Ramzi et al., 1999). Such wounds in major burns can be temporarily resurfaced with cadaver allograft or other biological dressings until donor autograft becomes available.

Wound excision should be performed on all burns as soon as we are sure that healing will not occur with conservative therapy. With regards to major burns, this takes place as soon as the patient becomes stable. Sequential surgeries are carried out on alternate days until all the eschar is removed. Mortality can be by reduced by minimising blood loss and control of body temperature during transport to and in the operating room. The former is achieved by use of tourniquets and topical application of adrenaline applied on nonadherent Telfa pads (Gomez et al., 2001).

There are two main techniques. In fascial excision the burn is excised down to the muscle fascia, removing all the skin and subcutaneous tissue. Its principal advantage is to offer a well-defined vascularised plane that is optimal for skin graft “take.” This is especially important where donor sites are limited since graft failure in these circumstances is likely to prove fatal. Furthermore, the excision can be rapidly performed with electrocuatery reducing blood loss. The major drawback, however, is that healthy subcutaneous tissue may be removed along with superficial nerves and lymphatics, producing severe contour deformities. It should be borne in mind that when this procedure is performed on the anterior trunk of a female the procedure incorporates a bilateral mastectomy.

The second technique is tangential excision and involves excising sequential layers in a tangential fashion until punctuate bleeding is seen from the underlying viable tissue. The instrument of choice is a Humby knife (Figure 4) or a Goulian Knife (Weck blade) for smaller and more delicate areas such as the face and hands and feet. Figure 4.
Tangential excision of burned leg.

sec.title: Skin grafting
sec.p: Autografts from nonburned skin remains the mainstay of treatment. For most adult patients, the antero-lateral thigh is the site of choice. Larger grafts can be harvested from the back, buttocks and abdomen. Such grafts can be expanded by a process of meshing to ratios ranging from 1:1 to 1:4. Meshing however comes with a cosmetic price, with scarring of the interstices, so that unmeshed or sheet grafts are used for sites seen by the public, such as the face, neck and hands.

sec.title: Grafting of burns over 90% TBSA
sec.p: Such massive injuries are particularly challenging. Any available site is harvested and used to cover the neck and clavicular areas so that our lines and any subsequent tracheostomy can be placed through good skin. At the same sitting a biopsy is taken for cultured epithelial autograft (CEA). The culture and transplantation of keratinocytes was considered a major advance in the treatment of severe burns whereby sufficient epithelial regeneration can occur under laboratory conditions and in 3 weeks transferred to the patient (Bannasch et al., 2003). Results, however, have been disappointing since lack of dermal component renders the new skin fragile and take is often poor. We have improved our results by using a sandwich technique. Skin is harvested from any available site. This includes the scalp and scrotum, facilitated by, tumescence with a 1:500,000 solution of adrenaline. The skin is meshed to a ratio of 4:1 and the CEA is placed over this.

Probably the best cover is ultimately achieved, however, by continual reharvesting of donor sites, typically reepithelialising every 2 weeks, and applying these widely meshed grafts while protecting the interstices with 2:1 meshed allograft in the so called Alexander Technique.

Attempts to achieve “off the shelf” skin has met with varying success. Yannas and Burke pioneered the use of a bilayered construct under the commercial name of Integra (Burke et al., 1994; Yannas et al., 2011). The epidermal component is composed of a sialastic membrane, and the dermal component is a porous matrix of fibres of cross-linked bovine collagen and a single GAG protein (chondroitin-6-sulphate). The neodermal component is incorporated into the wound bed within 3 weeks allowing the sialastic layer to be removed and a thin autograft applied. The process can be accelerated by use of negative pressure dressings, which also help splint the graft preventing shear. We have found Integra useful in burns of the hands and face and has an advantage in that it can be applied to relatively avascular areas such as small exposures over tendons and bone (Kosutic et al., 2012).

sec.title: Rehabilitation and psychology
sec.p: The goals of treatment are to prevent loss of motion, protect anatomic structures, prevent deformity and preserve skin graft integrity to promote functional independence. The position of comfort equals position of contracture. Techniques available to attempt to restore function include splinting, early motion (including soft tissue massage) and pressure therapy. Compression garments are applied as soon as the wounds have healed to help control scar hypertrophy (Simons et al., 2003).

The psychological burn-related issues are attended to as early as practicable. Common burn-related clinical issues may include: delirium, sleep derangements, pain, acute stress disorder, posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD), body image dissatisfaction and depression. Such services need to be provided on both an inpatient and outpatient basis in an effort to help patients and their families achieve maximum recovery (Blakeney et al., 2008).

sec.title: First 2 years (reconstruction)
sec.p:
The general guideline that reconstruction should not be undertaken until scars fully mature is trumped by concerns for tissue viability or progressive functional limitations, such as severe joint contractures, microstomia or ectropion and by patient and parent concerns regarding the impact of scarring and deformity on psychosocial development. Accurate diagnosis and planning is essential from the beginning. This is facilitated by the use of inventory forms which are divided into anatomical units (Brou et al., 1989). The photos (Figure 5(a) and (b)) show a patient who sustained acid burns to his face a year ago. Figure 5.
Extensive scarring following deep facial burns.

One can see alopecia of the scalp and bilateral eyebrows, loss of epicanthal folds causing a webbing appearance, loss of left nostril, lack of left alae and nasolabial fold, missing ears, loss of ear canal with hearing loss, flattening of his nasal bridge, scar contracture of the upper lip, commissure contracture, apart from extensive hypertrophic scarring in the presence of folliculits. Functional improvement is a priority. For this patient such reconstruction of his nasal airway was performed early. In other patients, associated neck contractures which impede anaesthesia or eyelid ectropion that endanger the cornea will have to be released urgently. The reconstructive ladder, as classically conceptualized, generally provides a hierarchical model for the choice of reconstructive techniques.

Burn wounds resulting in extensive scar contracture and tissue loss will require release and closure of the defect with split skin grafts (Robson et al., 1992), pedicled flaps or Z-plasty (Huang, 2007). Alopecia can be treated by tissue expansion and hair bearing transplantation. Ectropions of lip and eyelid are best corrected by release with full thickness skin. Musculoskeletal deformity or destruction may necessitate joint fusion, or repair with vascularised tissue.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Improvement in burn care has been driven by an explosion of technology and research, yet countless topics need to be addressed. These include: the roles of pharmacological agents to alter capillary leakage, molecular techniques to aid bacterial identification, immune enhancing nutrients, methods to improve scar control, use of hyperbaric oxygen and use of transplantation of composite tissue allograft. Advances in the care of the thermally injured patient have had a dramatic effect on improvement and prognosis of the patient over the last 50 years. Such translational research supports our multidisciplinary team involved in all phases described above.
